title: Architecture
content:
Architecture# The architecture block is the root element of any Sruja model. It represents the entire scope of what you are modeling.
Syntax# architecture "My System Name" { // ... define systems, persons, etc. here }Purpose# Scope Boundary: Everything inside is part of the model. Naming: Gives a name to the overall architecture.

title: Getting Started
content:
Getting Started with Sruja# This guide will help you install Sruja and create your first architecture model.
Installation# Automated Install (Recommended)# curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/sruja-ai/sruja/main/scripts/install.sh | bashManual Download# Download the latest release for your operating system from the GitHub Releases page.
From Source (Go)# If you have Go installed, you can still build from source:
go install github.com/sruja-ai/sruja/cmd/sruja@latestVerify the installation:
sruja --versionYour First Project# Create a file: Create a new file named architecture.sruja.
Write your model:
architecture "My System" { system App "My App" { container Web "Web Server" datastore DB "Database" } person User "User" User -> Web "Visits" Web -> DB "Reads/Writes" } Run Loading WASM... Visualize: Export to D2 to see the diagram.
sruja export d2 architecture.sruja > architecture.d2You can then render architecture.d2 using the D2 CLI or online playground.

title: Lesson 1: Introduction
content:
Lesson 1: Introduction to System Design# What is System Design?# System design is the process of defining the architecture, components, modules, interfaces, and data for a system to satisfy specified requirements. It is the bridge between business requirements and the final code.
The C4 Model# We use the C4 Model to visualize software architecture. It consists of four hierarchical levels:
Context: High-level view showing the system and its interactions with users and other systems. Container: Shows the applications and data stores that make up the system. Component: Shows the internal components within a container. Code: (Optional) Shows the implementation details (classes, interfaces). Why Sruja?# Sruja is a domain-specific language (DSL) for defining software architecture as code. It allows you to:
Version Control: Store your architecture in Git. Validate: Ensure your design meets requirements. Visualize: Generate diagrams automatically. Collaborate: Review designs like code. Your First Sruja File# Create a file named hello.sruja:
architecture "Hello World" { system MySystem "My First System" { description "A simple example system." } }Run the Sruja CLI to validate it:
sruja check hello.sruja Lesson Quiz# 1. What is the first level of the C4 model?
Context
Container Check Answer

title: Module 1: Fundamentals
content:
Module 1: Fundamentals# In this module, we will cover the foundational concepts of system design and how to start modeling with Sruja.
Lessons# Introduction System Context

title: 2. System Context
content:
Module 2: System Context# The System Context diagram is the starting point. It shows your system as a black box and how it interacts with the outside world.
Key Concepts# System: The software system you are building. Person: A user of the system (e.g., Customer, Admin). External System: Another software system that your system interacts with (e.g., Email Service, Payment Gateway). Defining Context in Sruja# In Sruja, you define these elements at the top level of the architecture block.
architecture "E-Commerce Context" { // The system we are building system ECommerce "E-Commerce Platform" { description "Allows customers to buy products online." } // Users person Customer "Online Customer" { description "A user who browses and buys products." } // External Systems system PaymentGateway "Stripe" { description "Handles payment processing." } system EmailService "SendGrid" { description "Sends transactional emails." } // Relationships Customer -> ECommerce "Browses & Buys" ECommerce -> PaymentGateway "Process Payments" ECommerce -> EmailService "Send Confirmations" }Best Practices# Focus on Value: Describe what the system does, not how it does it. Identify Actors: clearly identify who uses the system. External Dependencies: List all external systems you depend on.

title: Core Concepts
content:
Core Concepts# Sruja is built around the C4 Model for visualizing software architecture. It defines a hierarchy of abstractions:
Architecture: The root context. System: The highest level of abstraction. A software system. Container: Applications or data stores within a system (e.g., API, Web App, Database). Component: Modules or major structural building blocks within a container. Elements# Architecture System Container Component Person DataStore Queue Relations Deployment Dynamic Views

title: Module 2: Building Blocks
content:
Module 2: Building Blocks# This module focuses on the structural building blocks of your architecture: Containers and Components.
Lessons# Containers Components

title: System
content:
System# A System represents a software system, which is the highest level of abstraction in the C4 model. A system delivers value to its users, whether they are human or other systems.
Syntax# system ID "Label/Name" { description "Optional description" // ... contains containers }Example# system BankingSystem "Internet Banking System" { description "Allows customers to view accounts and make payments." }

title: 3. Containers
content:
Module 3: Containers# Once you understand the context, you zoom into the system to see its Containers. A container is a separately deployable unit that executes code or stores data.
Types of Containers# Web Application: Server-side (e.g., Java Spring) or Client-side (e.g., React). API Application: Provides an interface for other applications. Database: Stores data (e.g., PostgreSQL, MongoDB). Queue: Handles asynchronous messaging (e.g., Kafka, RabbitMQ). Mobile App: iOS or Android application. Defining Containers in Sruja# Containers live inside a system block.
architecture "E-Commerce Containers" { system ECommerce "E-Commerce Platform" { // Web Application container WebApp "Storefront" { technology "React" tags ["frontend"] } // API Service container API "Product API" { technology "Go / Gin" tags ["backend"] } // Database datastore DB "Product Database" { technology "PostgreSQL" description "Stores product catalog and inventory." } // Message Queue queue Events "Order Events" { technology "Kafka" } // Relationships within the system WebApp -> API "Fetches Data" { technology "HTTPS/JSON" } API -> DB "Reads/Writes" { technology "SQL" } API -> Events "Publishes OrderCreated" } }Technology Choices# Use the technology property to specify the stack. This is crucial for understanding the implementation constraints.
Using Properties and Styles# You can use the new properties and style blocks to add details and customize appearance.
container API "Product API" { technology "Go" properties { "framework": "Gin" "language_version": "1.21" } style { shape: "hexagon" color: "#00ADD8" } }

title: Container
DSL Reference
Module 3: Advanced Modeling
content:
Module 3: Advanced Modeling# Go beyond static structure to model how your system behaves and where it runs.
Lessons# Dynamic Views Deployment

title: 4. Components
content:
Module 4: Components# Inside a container, you can identify Components. A component is a grouping of related functionality encapsulated behind a well-defined interface.
When to Model Components?# You don’t always need to model components. Do it when:
The container is complex and needs breakdown. You want to document specific internal logic. You are designing a library or framework. Defining Components in Sruja# Components live inside a container block.
architecture "API Components" { system ECommerce "E-Commerce Platform" { container API "Product API" { technology "Go" component ProductController "Product Controller" { description "Handles HTTP requests for products." technology "Gin Handler" } component ProductService "Product Service" { description "Business logic for product management." } component ProductRepository "Product Repository" { description "Data access layer." } // Internal flow ProductController -> ProductService "Uses" ProductService -> ProductRepository "Uses" } } }Interfaces and Dependencies# Components should have clear responsibilities. Use relationships to show dependencies.
component AuthMiddleware "Auth Middleware" { description "Validates JWT tokens." } ProductController -> AuthMiddleware "Uses"

title: CLI Guide
content:
CLI Guide# The sruja command-line interface is your primary tool for interacting with Sruja projects.
Commands# export# Exports the architecture to various formats.
Usage:
sruja export [format] [file]Supported Formats:
d2: Generates D2 diagram code. Example:
sruja export d2 architecture.srujatree# Displays the architecture structure as a tree in the terminal.
Usage:
sruja tree --file [file]Options:
--json: Output as JSON. --system [ID]: Show tree for a specific system. Example:
sruja tree --file architecture.srujafmt# Formats the Sruja file to a canonical style.
Usage:
sruja fmt [file]check# Validates the Sruja file against rules and best practices.
Usage:
sruja check [file]

title: Component
content:
Component# A Component is a grouping of related functionality encapsulated behind a well-defined interface. Components reside inside Containers.
Syntax# component ID "Label/Name" { technology "Technology" // ... items }Example# component AuthController "Authentication Controller" { technology "Spring MVC Rest Controller" description "Handles user login and registration." }

title: Module 4: Production Readiness
content:
Module 4: Production Readiness# Ensure your design is ready for production with NFRs and ADRs, and test your knowledge.
Lessons# NFRs & Properties Course Quiz

title: 5. Dynamic Views
content:
Module 5: Dynamic Views# Static structure (Context, Containers, Components) tells you what the system is. Dynamic Views tell you how it works at runtime.
Use Cases# User Journeys: How a user completes a task (e.g., “Login”, “Checkout”). Data Flows: How data moves through the system. Algorithm Logic: Steps in a complex process. Defining Dynamic Views in Sruja# Use the dynamic block to define a sequence of interactions.
architecture "Checkout Flow" { system ECommerce "E-Commerce" { container Web "Web App" container API "API" datastore DB "Database" } person User "Customer" dynamic "Checkout Process" { description "User purchases items in cart." User -> Web "Clicks Checkout" Web -> API "POST /checkout" API -> DB "Validate Inventory" API -> DB "Create Order" API -> Web "Return Success" Web -> User "Show Confirmation" } }Journeys# Sruja also supports journey blocks for high-level user flows.
journey "User Login" { title "Customer logs in to the system" steps { User -> Web "Enters credentials" Web -> API "Authenticate" } }

title: Relations
6. Deployment
content:
Module 6: Deployment# The Deployment View shows how your containers are mapped to infrastructure nodes (servers, cloud services, etc.).
Key Concepts# Deployment Node: A physical or virtual environment (e.g., “AWS”, “Kubernetes Cluster”, “EC2 Instance”). Infrastructure Node: Supporting infrastructure (e.g., “Load Balancer”, “DNS”). Container Instance: An instance of a container running on a node. Defining Deployment in Sruja# Use the deployment block.
architecture "Production Deployment" { system ECommerce "E-Commerce" { container API "API Service" datastore DB "Database" } deployment "Production" { node "AWS" { node "US-East-1" { node "EKS Cluster" { containerInstance API { instanceId 1 } containerInstance API { instanceId 2 } } node "RDS" { containerInstance DB } } } } }Scaling# You can show multiple instances to represent horizontal scaling, as shown with the API container above.

title: Person
content:
Person# A Person represents a human user of your software system (e.g., “Customer”, “Admin”, “Employee”).
Syntax# person ID "Label" { description "Optional description" tags ["tag1", "tag2"] }Example# person Customer "Bank Customer" { description "A customer of the bank with personal accounts." }

title: 7. NFRs & Properties
content:
Module 7: NFRs & Properties# System design isn’t just about boxes and arrows. It’s about meeting Non-Functional Requirements (NFRs) like scalability, availability, and latency.
Defining Requirements# Sruja has a native requirement element.
requirement R1 performance "99th percentile latency < 100ms" requirement R2 availability "99.99% uptime" requirement R3 security "All data encrypted at rest"Using Properties for Calculations# You can use the properties block to store quantitative data about your system, which can be used for capacity planning calculations.
container API "API Service" { properties { "qps_peak": "10000" "avg_request_size": "5KB" "cpu_cores": "4" "memory": "8GB" } }Architecture Decision Records (ADRs)# Document your important decisions using adr.
adr ADR001 "Use PostgreSQL for relational data" adr ADR002 "Adopt Event Sourcing for Order Service"Connecting It All# Link requirements and ADRs to the elements they affect.
container API "API Service" { requirement R1 adr ADR001 }

title: DataStore
content:
DataStore# A DataStore represents a database, file system, or any other system that stores data. It is a specialized type of Container.
Syntax# datastore ID "Label" { description "Optional description" technology "Technology" }Example# datastore DB "Main Database" { technology "PostgreSQL" description "Stores user and order data" }

title: Queue
content:
Queue# A Queue represents a message queue, topic, or event stream. It is a specialized type of Container used for asynchronous communication.
Syntax# queue ID "Label" { description "Optional description" technology "Technology" }Example# queue Events "Event Stream" { technology "Kafka" description "Handles domain events" }

title: Deployment
content:
Deployment# The Deployment view allows you to map your software containers to infrastructure. This corresponds to the C4 Deployment Diagram.
Deployment Node# A Deployment Node is something like physical hardware, a virtual machine, a Docker container, a Kubernetes pod, etc. Nodes can be nested.
Syntax# deployment "Environment" { node "Node Name" { // ... } }Infrastructure Node# An Infrastructure Node represents infrastructure software that isn’t one of your containers (e.g., DNS, Load Balancer, External Database Service).
Syntax# node "App Server" { containerInstance WebApp }Container Instance# A Container Instance represents a runtime instance of one of your defined Containers running on a Deployment Node.
Syntax# containerInstance ContainerID { instanceId 1 // Optional }Example# deployment "Production" { node "AWS" { node "US-East-1" { node "App Server" { containerInstance WebApp } node "Database Server" { containerInstance DB } } } }

title: Dynamic Views
content:
Dynamic Views# Dynamic Views describe how elements (Containers, Components) interact at runtime to implement a specific user story or feature. This corresponds to the C4 Dynamic Diagram.
Syntax# dynamic "View Title" { description "Optional description" Source -> Destination "Description of interaction" // or Source -> Destination "Description" { order "1" // Explicit ordering } }Example# dynamic "Login Flow" { User -> WebApp "Submits credentials" WebApp -> AuthComponent "Validates credentials" AuthComponent -> DB "Checks user record" DB -> AuthComponent "Returns user data" AuthComponent -> WebApp "Returns token" WebApp -> User "Redirects to dashboard" }

title: System Design 101
content:
System Design 101# Welcome to the System Design 101 course! This course is designed to teach you the fundamentals of system design using the Sruja architecture language.
What you will learn# In this course, you will learn how to:
Model Systems: Understand the C4 model (Context, Containers, Components, Code) and how to represent it in Sruja. Design for Scale: Learn about scalability, load balancing, and partitioning. Choose Technologies: Make informed decisions about databases, queues, and protocols. Document Decisions: Use Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) to capture your design choices. Verify Requirements: Ensure your design meets functional and non-functional requirements. Course Modules# Module 1: Fundamentals Module 2: Building Blocks Module 3: Advanced Modeling Module 4: Production Readiness Prerequisites# Basic understanding of software development. Familiarity with command-line tools. Sruja CLI installed.

title: Metadata & Tags
content:
Metadata & Tags# Sruja allows you to attach additional information to your elements using Metadata and Tags.
Tags# Tags are simple string labels that can be used for filtering, styling, or categorization.
Syntax# tags ["tag1", "tag2"]Metadata# Metadata allows you to attach key-value pairs to elements. This is useful for storing information like team ownership, cost centers, links to other docs, etc.
Syntax# system API "API" { metadata { owner: "Team A" tier: "1" } }Technology# Most elements (Container, Component, etc.) support a technology field to specify the tech stack.
Syntax# metadata { key: "value" }

title: Examples
content:
Examples# Here are some complete examples of Sruja models. You can edit and run them directly in the playground.
Banking System# A simplified version of the C4 model banking system example.
architecture "Banking System" { system BankingSystem "Internet Banking System" { description "Allows customers to view accounts and make payments." container WebApp "Web Application" { technology "Java and Spring MVC" description "Delivers the static content and the Internet banking single page application." } container Database "Database" { technology "Oracle Database" description "Stores user registration information, hashed credentials, etc." } WebApp -> Database "Reads from and writes to" } person Customer "Personal Banking Customer" { description "A customer of the bank, with personal bank accounts." } Customer -> WebApp "Visits" } Run Loading WASM... Microservices# An example showing a microservices architecture.
architecture "E-Commerce" { system Shop "Online Shop" { container Frontend "Storefront" { technology "Next.js" } container Catalog "Catalog Service" { technology "Go" } container Orders "Order Service" { technology "Java" } datastore DB "Main DB" { technology "PostgreSQL" } Frontend -> Catalog "Browses items" Frontend -> Orders "Places orders" Catalog -> DB "Reads products" Orders -> DB "Writes orders" } person Shopper "Shopper" Shopper -> Frontend "Browses and buys" } Run Loading WASM...

title: Introduction
content:
Sruja: Architecture as Code# Sruja is a modern, developer-friendly language for defining software architecture. It allows you to describe your systems, containers, and components using a clean, C4-model-based DSL, and then generate diagrams, documentation, and more.
Why Sruja?# Code-First# Treat your architecture like code. Version control it, review it, and evolve it. Sruja files are plain text, making them easy to diff and merge. This allows you to integrate architectural decision-making into your existing development workflows (Pull Requests, Code Reviews).
C4 Model# Built-in support for the C4 model (System, Container, Component) ensures a standardized way to describe software. You don’t need to invent your own boxes and arrows; Sruja provides the primitives you need to describe software systems at different levels of abstraction.
Diagrams as Code# Generate beautiful diagrams (via D2) automatically from your model. No more dragging boxes around in Visio or Lucidchart. When your code changes, your diagrams update automatically. This ensures your documentation never goes stale.
Validation# Ensure your architecture follows best practices with built-in validation rules. Sruja can check for things like:
Orphaned elements (defined but not connected). Circular dependencies. Missing descriptions or technology tags. Compliance with architectural policies. Key Features# Simple DSL# The Sruja DSL is designed to be easy to read and write. It uses a familiar C-style syntax with braces for grouping.
system "MySystem" { container "WebApp" { technology "Go" } }D2 Export# Sruja exports directly to D2, a modern diagram scripting language. D2 handles the layout and routing, producing high-quality SVG diagrams that look professional and are easy to read.
Validation Engine# Catch architectural smells early. The validation engine runs every time you build or check your model, providing immediate feedback on the health of your architecture.
Extensible# Built for the future. Sruja is designed to be extensible, allowing for new export formats, custom validation rules, and integration with other tools in your ecosystem.
Getting Started# Ready to dive in? Check out the Getting Started guide to install Sruja and build your first model.
Community# Join the community to discuss architecture, share models, and contribute to Sruja.
